reviewText:
Seven Kingdoms 2 is my favourite RTS game ever and this HD version added some much-needed higher resolutions.

7K2 originally came out in 1999. When compared to the major RTS game of the time, the Age Of Empires franchise has better quality graphics and more detailed combat with the sheer number of unit types and combat options at your disposal (however in 7K2, you can control multiple nationalities at once, allowing you to use their unit types for war and opening up more combat possibilities)

Both franchises are great, but if you want a game that is more about empire building, with amazing diplomacy, strategy, espionage and economy management on a national scale; look no further than 7K2.

For those interested and want to know how it compares to Age Of Empires, here's what you have in Seven Kingdoms 2:

- DETAILED LOYALTY SYSTEM: Rule your kingdom by fair means or foul. Each person/unit in your kingdom has a loyalty value that's affected by your decisions. For example, if you're an evil ruler, be prepared to control towns that may want to rebel or soldiers who try to defect to another kingdom
- MEANINGFUL AND INTRICATE DIPLOMACY OPTIONS
- EXPANSION: SK2 includes towns that are independent of other nations. Expand your kingdom by taking over these towns through gaining their trust or by tyranny.
- MULTICULTURAL RULE: Control more than one race at a time by taking over independent towns of other nationalities.
- PLAYABLE MONSTER RACES (called Frythans) that greatly diversify strategy and gameplay
- DETAILED ECONOMIC MANAGEMENT: mine, manufacture and distribute 3 types of resources, establish trade routes between towns and nations, establish a tax system for your towns
- EXCELLENT ESPIONAGE SYSTEMS (agitate, assassinate, counter-spy, create an incident between two nations, steal technologies and bribing)
- RPG ELEMENTS: Each unit (soldier or civilian) has their own name, as well as combat, leadership and loyalty stats that can be improved with more experience
- HEROS: rule with legends such as Genghis Khan, Hannibal Barca or Alexander The Great
- A randomly generated campaign storyline that is different each time you play it (although it's somewhat glitchy at times...)

This HD version is essentially the same game with some higher resolution settings and some patches to gameplay.

I've seen on forums that some people have had problems running the game, thankfully I haven't had any of these issues.

reviewText:
Don't be discouraged by the outdated graphics and sound. This game is truly a unique gem and easily forgotten but offers so much even today despite it's somewhat dated looks.

In Seven Kingdoms you take control of an human civilization on a typical rts styled map, you can pick between 12 civilizations which all look aesthetically different and have various strengths/weaknesses. Furthermore you can pick a Frythan race, which are mythical and gruesome creatures bent on enslaving everyone. Both factions play very different, where human civilizations are more refined and deep, the Frythans are more about conquering.

The game has some very unique mechanics, basically the player tries to take over towns (either peacefully or with force) to increase your population. Recruiting them as builders or soldiers from a pool. Diplomacy, wafare, research and espionage are of utmost importance and allow you for different playstyles. You can pick between various approaches to conquer your enemies which is certainly a welcome change, it's a lot deeper than your typical rts. It has some major 4x elements so there are a lot of factors that you have to consider. The Frythan faction is more straight forward though with a heavy emphasis on warfare. The campaign is certainly unique and has some Risk elements, don't expect anything amazing but it's still very entertaining. I definitely recommend this game for the multiplayer though, playing with a friend is a blast.

The things that I could critique is the dated graphics and sound assets, but I personally don't mind it that much. It is servicable and still quite good. Also sometimes it can be a bit confusing if there is a lot of activity going on, there are sometimes a lot of factors to manage but luckily the hd edition allows for a larger overview, making it easier to navigate. Which reminds me that this game can be extremely challenging at first, the AI is actually really competent and can easily wipe you out even if you consider yourself an expert at rts games.

Still I definitely recommend this game for anyone who likes a somewhat unique rts with a nice twist. It offers variety from other games and runs on every pc.

reviewText:
TLDR: A great and unique real time strategy game with multifaceted gameplay.

I already have a copy but I when I saw it on steam I had to get it again just so it's there in my library. You'll need to look past the outdated graphics, the mechanics and gameplay is what makes this RTS stand out.

There are some cool unique mechanics that makes me always come back to this game. Firstly, military units have two general stats: combat and leadership. Combat affects the units health and damage. Leadership applies a combat bonus to all troops under that General's command and also increases the rate at which the General can train their troops up in combat. Any military unit can be promoted to a General. When you recruit your military, they start off weak, but through combat and training from general they improve dramatically. Which means, a small group of veterans often can take on large forces of fresh recruits. This makes for some interesting gameplay.

I really enjoy the economic aspect of this game. This game only has two resources, food and money. You own towns which generate food as long as there are farmers. Money is also generated by towns via taxes, or via trading. But whats cool is for money, one needs to manage it well as there are maintainence costs. Rather than the usual gather resources and spend it, you always need to keep in mind do you have enough income coming in to sustain your expansion. So you really need to balance your economic versus your military / spy network expansion. Expand to quickly, and you'll go into debt whereby all your buildings start taking damage from poor maintenance and all your troops and citizens start becoming less loyal.

Another aspect of the game that is enjoyable is the spy networks you can build. Do not understimate the power of distration during war where you can sneak spies into enemy forts and bribe their generals. Nothing beats having a huge army storm towards your base, only to get the generals to defect to yourself and watch as half of the enemy's army follow their generals and joins you as well.

There is a lot to the game and it would be impossible to cover it all here. If you love strategy, RTS, and are looking for unique and fresh gameplay then this game is for you.

reviewText:
If you played SK2 before and know what's it about: get it! The HD graphics are great and they added a new extra-large map mode, which also brings a nice touch to an old formula.

If you never played SK2 before: SK2HD is basically a strategy game that mixes politics heavily into the flow, bringing forth some really Game of Thrones moments. Some features simplified:

- you have only 2 types of unit per kingdom + your god. Basic units can be created from the get-go and fill forts, in which they train under potent commanders. After x Combat points they unlock a special attack (usually a range attack or a more powerful melee attack)
- the two resources in the game (food and money) are managed through economy and agriculture. For economy you need to creat markets connected to factories connected to mines. for agriculture,  you need a village  that has as many free people as possible (mines/factories/laboratories require manpower, which is subtracted from the village worker force).
- diplomacy is the name of the game. you will have to carefully select your friends and allies and join wars with caution. a war will weaken your kingdom and make it vulnerable to new attacks. You will also loose seasoned warriors and, in the worst case scenario, generals.
- espionage is a potent tool in this game. you can sabotage production, stir an uprising, bribe soldiers/generals to join your side (as spies themselves), capture forts (if your spy is the general) and even hand over the entire kingdom to your side (if, by some miracle, the other king dies and one of your spies is selected as king
- mercenary units can be bought and make excellent troops, especially when you have to hold an advancing force while your main army reaches the battle (pro-tip: builds LOTS of inns)

It's an easy game to learn, yet pretty complex, since it requires careful planning and knowing exactly when to jump in the world war (all maps eventually end in world wars). Jumping in to soon might weaken your kingdom and turn you into prey for whoever will end up victorious. Jumping too late, however, might see you facing a kingdom that is spread over the entire map and who's army outnumbers yours 10 to 1.

Like in real politics, wait and see which side begins to dominate the map and join the other one.


There's also monsters in the game. They can't do diplomacy (even if they want to), which makes them far less fun but more of a challenge.
